JUDGES: Angelika Nußberger;Ann Power-Forde;Dean Spielmann;Elisabet Fura;Ganna Yudkivska;Mark Villiger
TEXT: The applicant , PERSON Terletskaya , is a NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in PERSON . ORG ( “ the Government ” ) were represented by their former Agent , Mr PERSON , from ORG .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .
The applicant worked as an assistant in a shop belonging to Mr. PERSON
On DATE a tax police squad visited Mr F. ’s shop in order to carry out an unscheduled inspection due to PERSON failure to submit tax returns .
The inspection was not conducted , as Mr F. , his relatives and his employees , including the applicant , prevented the officers from accessing the store ’s tax records . It led to a fracas .

As was later established by the investigation , at some point Mr F. switched off the light and the applicant screamed that she had been punched in her face by tax officer PERSON escalated the scuffle and PERSON tried to leave the scene in his car . Mr F. and the applicant tried to prevent PERSON from leaving . Mr F. jumped on the hood of the car , then broke a side window and tried to pull officer PERSON out of the car , while the applicant blocked the rear of the car and jumped on it when the car tried to move . Tax officer PERSON tried to pull the applicant away from the car .
DATE , the applicant lodged a complaint with the PERSON police department against officer PERSON for punching her in her face .
Again on DATE , the members of the tax police squad that had conducted the inspection gave statements to the police .
At TIME the applicant was examined by a doctor , who found a bruise on her right arm .

On DATE the applicant lodged a complaint against tax police officers PERSON and PERSON with ORG . She complained that officer PERSON had beaten her and that officer PERSON had “ applied brutal physical force ” to her .

On the same date the applicant was questioned and underwent a medical examination . The examination revealed the following injuries on her : CARDINAL bruise of CARDINAL x QUANTITY on the inner side of the right forearm ; CARDINAL bruise of QUANTITY just above the left buttock ; and CARDINAL bruise of QUANTITY on the outer surface of the right thigh .
Again on the same date , the tax inspectorate transferred the applicant ’s complaint to ORG ( “ the ORG ” ) , which started an investigation .
On DATE ORG conducted an internal query and concluded that the tax police had acted lawfully in conducting the tax inspection of PERSON shop .

On DATE the applicant underwent a forensic medical examination ordered by the investigator . The forensic expert concluded that the applicant ’s injuries certified by the medical examination of DATE could have been caused by blunt hard objects , including by jumping on the car and grasping its metal parts and by having been pulled off the car by officer L.
On several occasions the investigation questioned the individuals involved in the scuffle and some by - passers who had witnessed the beginning of the scuffle .

On DATE the ORG refused to institute criminal proceedings against officers PERSON and L. The investigation established that on DATE a squad of CARDINAL officers had arrived at Mr F ’s shop in order to conduct a tax inspection . Mr F. had refused to give them access to financial documentation . The squad had called their supervisor , PERSON , who had arrived at the shop with a lawyer to draft a report recording that it had been impossible to conduct the inspection . At that time , the applicant had arrived at the shop to start her shift as an assistant . When the members of the squad had tried to read out the document , PERSON had switched off the light , claiming that the shop ’s TIME were over , and had started pushing the squad ’s officers out of the shop . When they were out in front of the shop , Mr F. had temporarily switched off the light in front of the shop and the applicant had then started shouting that PERSON had punched her in her face . Following that , PERSON and his relatives and other shop assistants that had been present had blocked PERSON ’s car , preventing it from leaving . The applicant had been jumping on the back of the car . Meanwhile , Mr F. had jumped on the hood of the car and , kicking the wind shield , had broken it . Mr F. had then broken CARDINAL of the car ’s side windows and , trying to pull PERSON PERSON out of the car , had cut his hand on the broken glass . At the same time , officer PERSON had tried to pull the applicant away from the car but she had resisted .

The investigator further noted the results of the forensic medical examination of the applicant and its conclusions that the applicant could have caused the minor bodily harm established herself by jumping on the car or that her injuries could have been caused by officer PERSON when he had tried to pull her away from it . The investigator also noted that the applicant had not had any injuries on her face .

As it could not be established that the bodily harm ascertained had been caused to the applicant by the tax police officers , the investigator refused to institute criminal proceedings against officers PERSON and PERSON for a lack of corpus delicti .

On DATE ORG quashed the decision of DATE and instructed the ORG to conduct additional investigation on the grounds that officers PERSON and PERSON had not been questioned and that the decision of DATE had mistakenly been taken within the criminal proceedings against PERSON and not in connection with the preliminary examination of the applicant ’s complaint .
On DATE officers PERSON and PERSON were questioned again .
On DATE the ORG refused to institute criminal proceedings .
On DATE the applicant lodged a private prosecution with ORG . On DATE the court left the complaint without consideration for failure to comply with procedural formalities .

On DATE the ORG quashed the ORG ’s decision of CARDINAL DATE and returned the case to the ORG for further investigation . It noted that the decision of DATE had mistakenly been taken within the criminal proceedings against PERSON and not in connection with the preliminary examination of the applicant ’s complaint and that PERSON had not been questioned as witnesses .
In DATE Mr F. and PERSON were questioned .

On DATE the ORG refused to institute criminal proceedings . It was noted that there was no objective proof that officer PERSON had punched the applicant in her face at all , that the applicant ’s other injuries could have been caused by her jumping on the car and that it could not be established beyond reasonable doubt that officer PERSON had caused any of the minor injuries found on the applicant .
On DATE the ORG rejected the applicant ’s subsequent appeal against the decision of DATE .
On DATE ORG upheld the decision of the first - instance court .
On DATE ORG upheld the decisions of the lower courts .
The applicant lodged CARDINAL administrative complaints against ORG for its alleged failure to act on her complaints .

On DATE and CARDINAL DATE ORG found that ORG had failed to consider criminal complaints which the applicant had brought against ORG . The court ordered ORG to consider the applicant ’s complaints and to take reasoned decisions on them .
The applicant maintained that the court decisions of CARDINAL DATE and DATE DATE have remained unenforced .
